translated: The Paṭṭhāna Treatise🔽The reverse order of the dependent origination, the commentary on the Paṭṭhāna text

analyzed: dhamma paccanīya anuloma tika tika paṭṭhāna pāḷi  ācaya gāmittika kusalattika
translated: The section on the wholesome factors that lead to accumulation, the section on the wholesome factors

original: Naācayagāmiṁ nakusalaṁ dhammaṁ paccayā ācayagāmī kusalo dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā. (Saṅkhittaṁ.) Hetuyā cha …pe… avigate cha.
analyzed: na ācaya gāmim na kusalam dhammam paccayā ācaya gāmī kusalaḥ dhammo uppajjati hetu paccayā saṅkhitta hetuyā cha pe avigate cha
translated: With factors that lead to accumulation and are wholesome as condition, wholesome factors that lead to accumulation arise – by way of condition being a cause. (In brief.) With regard to the cause, there are six; … with regard to the unobscured, there are six.

original: Naācayagāmiṁ naakusalaṁ dhammaṁ paccayā ācayagāmī akusalo dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā. (Saṅkhittaṁ.) Hetuyā tīṇi …pe… avigate tīṇi.
analyzed: na ācaya gāmim na akusalam dhammam paccayā ācaya gāmī akusalaḥ dhammo uppajjati hetu paccayā saṅkhitta hetuyā tīṇi pe avigate tīṇi
translated: With factors that do not lead to accumulation and are unwholesome as condition, unwholesome factors that lead to accumulation arise – by way of condition being a cause. (In brief.) With regard to the cause, there are three; … with regard to the unobscured, there are three.

original: Naācayagāmiṁ naabyākataṁ dhammaṁ paṭicca nevācayagāmināpacayagāmī abyākato dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā. (Saṅkhittaṁ.) Hetuyā pañca, adhipatiyā pañca …pe… avigate pañca.
analyzed: na ācaya gāmim na abyākatam dhammam paṭicca na iva ācaya gāminā apacaya gāmī abyākataḥ dhammaḥ uppajjati hetu paccayā saṅkhitta hetuyā pañca adhipatiyā pañca pe avigate pañca
translated: With factors that do not lead to accumulation and are indeterminate as condition, factors that neither lead to accumulation nor to diminution and are indeterminate arise – by way of condition being a cause. (In brief.) With regard to the cause, there are five; with regard to the dominant, there are five; … with regard to the unobscured, there are five.
